citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
In the petting zoo section of the park, an alpaca was observed to have lower incisors that were excessively long and
sticking out of its mouth. The alpaca had a good body condition. When asked, the Attending Veterinarian said it had been
six months since they had been trimmed. Dental issues can be painful and can cause the animal not to eat. The licensee
must have the teeth trimmed and must have them trimmed on a more regular basis so the teeth don't get excessively long
again.

When the general public enters the main building on site, they walk right past the serval enclosure. The sidewalk leading
up to the building comes right up to the corner of the serval enclosure. People walking past can easily stick their hands
into the enclosure as there is no barrier in between the enclosure and the sidewalk preventing them from doing so. Not
having proper barriers in place doesn't ensure the safety of the animals or the public. A barrier must be established to
assure the safety of the animals and the public.

Two of the primate enclosures had rust covered beams that the primates were able to come into contact with. Rust in the
enclosures doesn't allow for the proper cleaning and sanitization of that enclosure. The rust needs to be removed or
covered in a manner so as to prevent the primates from coming into contact with it.

Carrots stored in the fridge were observed to have black spots on them and were soft to the touch indicating they have
spoiled. Spoiled food fed to the animals can result in illness. Spoiled food must be discarded in a timely manner and must
not be fed to any animals.
Note: This was corrected during the inspection.

In the rear section of the park that housed the majority of the hoof stock a zebu was observed to be holding its right front
leg up. When asked the licensee stated the zebu is under veterinary treatment. He stated the animal was injured from a
fight with a cow. Animals housed in the same enclosure that are not compatible with each other can result in fighting and
injuries as is the case here. Animals shall not be housed near or with other animals that interfere with their health or
cause them discomfort. These two animals should be separated as they have shown they are not compatible being
housed in the same enclosure.
Note: These two animals were separated prior to inspection.

An emu was observed to have a loss of feathers with the pin heads of the feathers showing. When asked the licensee
stated the ostrich has been plucking the feathers of the emu. At one point during inspection, we observed the ostrich to
pick/pluck at the emu as it went past the ostrich. A bird constantly having its feathers plucked by another bird can be
stressful to that bird. In addition, the bird's feathers help protect the bird from the elements of the weather. Birds may not
be housed with other animals unless they are compatible. The licensee must separate these two birds from each other as
the ostrich has shown it is not compatible with the emu.
This is a (1st/2nd) Re-License Inspection for a Class (“A”/ “B”/ “C”) license. The inspection and exit briefing were
conducted with the applicant.
All items must be in compliance within (2 / 1) more inspection(s) or by (date-60 days counted from 1st RL Inspection) or
the applicant will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your
next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
KEVIN WILKEN, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
